{{redirect|Death by a thousand cuts}} {{italic}} {{Use dmy dates|date=May 2012}} [[File:Martyrerp 2.jpg|thumb|350px|An 1858 illustration from the French newspaper ''[[Le Monde illustré]]'', of the ''lingchi'' execution of a French missionary, [[Auguste Chapdelaine]], in China. Actually, Chapdelaine died from physical abuse in prison, and was beheaded after death.]] {{infobox Chinese |title=''Lingchi'' |pic=Lingchi (Chinese characters).svg |piccap="''Lingchi'' in Traditional (top) and Simplified (bottom) Chinese characters |picupright=0.375 |t=凌遲 |s=凌迟 |p=língchí |w=ling<sup>2</sup>-ch'ih<sup>2</sup> |mi={{IPAc-cmn|l|ing|2|.|ch|^|2}} |j=ling<sup>4</sup>-ci<sup>4</sup> |y=lìhng-chìh |ci={{IPAc-yue|l|ing|4|.|c|i|4}} |tl=lêng-tî }} '''''Lingchi''''' ({{zh|t=凌遲}}), translated variously as the '''slow process''', the '''lingering death''', or '''slow slicing''', and also known as '''death by a thousand cuts''', was a form of torture and [[execution]] used in [[China]] from roughly 900 CE until it was banned in 1905. It was also used in [[Vietnam]]. In this form of execution, a knife was used to methodically remove portions of the body over an extended period of time, eventually resulting in death.
''Lingchi'' was reserved for crimes viewed as especially severe, such as treason. Some Westerners were executed in this manner. Even after the practice was outlawed, the concept itself has still appeared across many types of media.
== Etymology == The term ''lingchi'' first appeared in a line in Chapter 28 of the classical philosophical text ''[[Xunzi (book)|Xunzi]]''. The line originally described the difficulty in travelling in a horse-drawn carriage on mountainous terrain.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Xun|first1=Kuang|authorlink1=Xun Kuang|title=Xunzi|date=3rd century BCE|location=China|chapter=28|quote=三尺之岸而虛車不能登也，百仞之山任負車登焉，何則？陵遲故也。|url=http://ctext.org/xunzi/you-zuo}}</ref> Later on, it was used to describe the prolonging of a person's agony when the person is being killed.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Shen|first1=Jiaben|title=历代刑法考 [Research on Judicial Punishments over the Dynasties]|date=2006|publisher=[[Zhonghua Book Company]]|location=China|isbn=9787101014631|url=https://book.douban.com/subject/1944166/|language=Chinese}}</ref>
==Description== The process involved tying the condemned prisoner to a wooden frame, usually in a public place. The flesh was then cut from the body in multiple slices in a process that was not specified in detail in Chinese law, and therefore most likely varied. The punishment worked on three levels: as a form of public humiliation, as a slow and lingering death, and as a punishment after death.
According to the [[Confucianism|Confucian]] principle of [[filial piety]], to alter one's body or to cut the body are considered unfilial practices. ''Lingchi'' therefore contravenes the demands of filial piety. In addition, to be cut to pieces meant that the body of the victim would not be "whole" in spiritual life after death. This method of execution became a fixture in the image of China among some Westerners.<ref>{{Citation|last=Morrison|first=JM|title=Twentieth Century: The History of the World, 1901 to 2000|year=2000}}.</ref>
''Lingchi'' could be used for the torture and execution of a living person, or applied as an act of humiliation after death. It was meted out for major offences such as [[high treason]], [[mass murder]], [[patricide]]/[[matricide]] or the murder of one's master or employer.<ref>{{cite web|script-title=zh:清李毓昌命案 于保业|trans-title=The Qing Dynasty Case of Li Yuchang|url=http://www.jimo.gov.cn/jmwenhuaju/inc/list.asp?id=16991&webid=171|language=Chinese|date=2006|location=[[Jimo]]|publisher=Jimo Cultural Network|accessdate=25 May 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120805150939/http://www.jimo.gov.cn/jmwenhuaju/inc/list.asp?id=16991&webid=171|archivedate=5 August 2012|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Emperors used it to threaten people and sometimes ordered it for minor offences.<ref>[[Hongwu Emperor]]. ''大誥'' [''Letters Patent'']</ref><ref>文秉 [Wen Bing]. ''先撥志始'' [Volume One of the History]</ref> There were forced convictions and wrongful executions.<ref>王世貞 [Shizhen (1526–90)]. ''弇山堂别集'' [''Yanshan Hall Collection''], vol. 97</ref><ref>劉若愚 [Liu Ruoyu (1584–?)]. ''酌中志'' [Discretion in Chi], vol. 2</ref> Some emperors meted out this punishment to the family members of their enemies.<ref>{{cite journal|title=沈万三家族覆灭记 |trans-title=Destruction of the Shen Manzo family |url=http://www.0512yy.com/showart.asp?id=3324 |date=25 May 2007 |journal=Suzhou Magazine (苏州杂志) |language=Chinese |issn=1005-1651 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151227045456/http://www.0512yy.com/showart.asp?id=3324 |archivedate=27 December 2015 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite book|author=Gu Yingtai (谷應泰) (1620–90)|title=明史紀事本末|trans-title=Major Events in Ming History|volume=18 |language=Chinese}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|title=國朝典故·立閑齋錄|trans-title=Ming Dynasty History|language=Chinese}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=太平天國.1|trans-title=Taiping.1|url=http://blog.udn.com/joeee3/3718452|date=25 January 2010|website=[[United Daily News|UDN]]|language=Chinese|access-date=27 December 2015}}</ref>
While it is difficult to obtain accurate details of how the executions took place, they generally consisted of cuts to the arms, legs, and chest leading to amputation of limbs, followed by decapitation or a stab to the heart. If the crime was less serious or the executioner merciful, the first cut would be to the throat causing death; subsequent cuts served solely to dismember the corpse.
Art historian [[James Elkins (art critic)|James Elkins]] argues that extant photos of the execution clearly show that the "death by division" (as it was termed by German criminologist {{Interlanguage link multi|Robert Heindl|de}}) involved some degree of [[dismemberment]] while the subject was living.<ref>Elkins, James, ''The Object Stares Back: On the Nature of Seeing'', New York: Simon and Schuster, 1996</ref> Elkins also argues that, contrary to the apocryphal version of "death by a thousand cuts", the actual process could not have lasted long. The condemned individual is not likely to have remained conscious and aware (if even alive) after one or two severe wounds, so the entire process could not have included more than a "few dozen" wounds.
In the [[Yuan dynasty]], 100 cuts were inflicted<ref>[[Guan Hanqing|Guan, Hanqing]]. ''[[The Injustice to Dou E]]''.</ref> but by the [[Ming dynasty]] there were records of 3,000 incisions.<ref>Deng, Zhicheng (鄧之誠). ''Gu Dong Xu Ji'' (骨董續記), vol. 2.</ref><ref>''Yu Qiao Hua Zheng Ben Mo'' (漁樵話鄭本末)</ref> It is described as a fast process lasting no longer than 15 to 20 minutes.<ref name=Bourgon2004ID248CF2Fa2>{{cite web|editor-last=Bourgon|editor-first=Jérôme |last1=Bourgon|first1=Jérôme|last2=Detrie|first2=Muriel|last3=Poulet|first3=Regis|title=Execution in Canton|url=http://turandot.chineselegalculture.org/Textual.php?ID=248&CF=2&Fa=2|date=2004|website=Chinese Torture - Supplices Chinois|publisher=IAO: Institut d'Asie Orientale|language=English, French|accessdate=25 May 2015}}</ref> Available photographic records<ref name=Bourgon2004ID1>{{cite web|editor-last=Bourgon|editor-first=Jérôme|title=Execution of Fu-zhu-li|url=http://turandot.chineselegalculture.org/Event.php?ID=1|date=2004|website=Chinese Torture - Supplices Chinois|publisher=IAO: Institut d'Asie Orientale|language=English, French|accessdate=25 May 2015}}</ref><ref name=Bourgon2004ID8/> seem to prove the speed of the event as the crowd remains consistent across the series of photographs. Moreover, these photographs show a striking contrast between the stream of blood that soaks the left flank of the victim and the lack of blood on the right side, possibly showing that the first or the second cut has reached the heart.<ref>{{Citation|url=http://turandot.chineselegalculture.org/Photographs.php?ID=39|title=Lingchi C, 2nd cut (a)|date=10 April 1905|publisher=CNRS}}.</ref><ref>{{Citation|publisher=CNRS|title=Lingchi A, 2nd cut (breasts)|date=31 October 1904|url=http://turandot.chineselegalculture.org/Photographs.php?ID=130}}.</ref> The ''[[coup de grâce]]'' was all the more certain when the family could afford a bribe to have a stab to the heart inflicted first.<ref>{{cite web |title=狱中杂记 |trans-title=Miscellaneous Records from Prison |url=http://www.ndcnc.gov.cn/datalib/2003/Literature/DL/DL-174122 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20070621221957/http://www.ndcnc.gov.cn/datalib/2003/Literature/DL/DL-174122 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2007-06-21 |website=National Digital Cultural Network |language=Chinese}}</ref> Some emperors ordered three days of cutting<ref>Shen, Defu (沈德符). ''Wan Li Ye Huo Bian'' (萬曆野獲編), vol. 28.</ref><ref>Zhang, Wenlin (張文麟). ''Duan Yan Gong Nian Pu'' (端巖公年譜).</ref> while others may have ordered specific tortures before the execution,<ref>[http://dspace.xmu.edu.cn/dspace/bitstream/2288/20359/1/1815%E5%B9%B4%E5%8F%B0%E6%B9%BE%E7%B1%8D%E5%A4%AA%E7%9B%91%E6%9E%97%E8%A1%A8%E4%B9%8B%E6%AD%BB.pdf Death of the Taiwanese eunuch Lin Biao (台湾籍太监林表之死)]{{dead link|date=May 2012}}</ref> or a longer execution.<ref>Yanbei Laoren (燕北老人). ''Qingdai Shisan Chao Gongwei Mishi'' (清代十三朝宫闱秘史).</ref><ref>Xu, Ke (徐珂). ''Qing Bai Lei Chao'' (清稗類鈔).</ref><ref>[http://lin61930726.pixnet.net/blog/post/30987636 Lingchi - The Most Dreaded Form of Execution (Enter with Caution) (「凌遲」最駭人的死刑5 (慎入))] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100425065529/http://lin61930726.pixnet.net/blog/post/30987636 |date=25 April 2010 }}. Pixnet (22 April 2010). Retrieved 20 May 2012.</ref> For example, records showed that during [[Yuan Chonghuan]]'s execution, Yuan was heard shouting for half a day before his death.<ref>Ji, Liuqi (計六奇). ''Ming Ji Bei Lue'' (明季北略), vol. 5.</ref>
The flesh of the victims may also have been sold as medicine.<ref>Ji, Liuqi (計六奇). ''Ming Ji Bei Lue'' (明季北略), vol. 15.</ref> As an official punishment, death by slicing may also have involved slicing the bones, cremation, and scattering of the deceased's ashes.
==Western perceptions== The Western perception of ''lingchi'' has often differed considerably from the actual practice, and some misconceptions persist to the present. The distinction between the sensationalised Western myth and the Chinese reality was noted by Westerners as early as 1895. That year, Australian traveller [[George Ernest Morrison]], who claimed to have witnessed an execution by slicing, wrote that "''lingchi'' [was] commonly, and quite wrongly, translated as 'death by slicing into 10,000 pieces' — a truly awful description of a punishment whose cruelty has been extraordinarily misrepresented... The mutilation is ghastly and excites our horror as an example of barbarian cruelty; but it is not cruel, and need not excite our horror, since the mutilation is done, not before death, but after."<ref>{{cite web|editor1-first=Jerome|editor1-last=Bourgon|editor2-first=Muriel|editor2-last=Detrie|editor3-first=Regis|editor3-last=Poulet|url=http://turandot.chineselegalculture.org/Textual.php?ID=167&CF=2&Fa=2|last=Morrison|first=George Ernest|publisher=CNRS|location=Lyon, FR|title=Turandot|accessdate=30 July 2009}}</ref>
According to apocryphal lore, ''lingchi'' began when the torturer, wielding an extremely sharp knife, began by putting out the eyes, rendering the condemned incapable of seeing the remainder of the torture and, presumably, adding considerably to the psychological terror of the procedure. Successive rather minor cuts chopped off ears, nose, tongue, fingers, toes and genitals before proceeding to cuts that removed large portions of flesh from more sizable parts, e.g., thighs and shoulders.
The entire process was said to last three days, and to total 3,600 cuts. The heavily carved bodies of the deceased were then put on a parade for a show in the public.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.manchestereventsguide.co.uk/feature/Death_by_a_Thousand_Cuts_at_Chinese_Arts_Centre_18th_January_to_23rd_March/114.html|title=Death by a Thousand Cuts at Chinese Arts Centre 18th January to 23rd March|publisher=Manchester events guide|accessdate=2009-07-30|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090418031632/http://www.manchestereventsguide.co.uk/feature/Death_by_a_Thousand_Cuts_at_Chinese_Arts_Centre_18th_January_to_23rd_March/114.html|archive-date=18 April 2009|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Some victims were reportedly given doses of [[opium]] to alleviate suffering.{{citation needed|date=January 2016}}
[[John Roberts (historian)|John Morris Roberts]], in ''Twentieth Century: The History of the World, 1901 to 2000'' (2000), writes "the traditional punishment of death by slicing... became part of the western image of Chinese backwardness as the 'death of a thousand cuts.'" Roberts then notes that slicing "was ordered, in fact, for [[Kang Youwei|K'ang Yu-Wei]], a man termed the '[[Jean-Jacques Rousseau|Rousseau]] of China', and a major advocate of intellectual and government reform in the 1890s."<ref>Roberts, p. 60, footnote 8.</ref>
Although officially outlawed by the government of the [[Qing dynasty]] in 1905,<ref>{{Cite journal|url=http://journals.cambridge.org/action/displayAbstract?fromPage=online&aid=181371|title=Abolishing 'Cruel Punishments': A Reappraisal of the Chinese Roots and Long-term Efficiency of the Xinzheng Legal Reforms|journal=Modern Asian Studies|volume=37|issue=4|pages=851–862|date=8 October 2003|accessdate=30 July 2009|doi=10.1017/S0026749X03004050|last1=Bourgon|first1=Jérôme}}</ref> ''lingchi'' became a widespread Western symbol of the Chinese penal system from the 1910s on, and in [[Zhao Erfeng]]'s administration.<ref>{{Citation|url=http://www.phayl.com/news/article.aspx?id=24749|title=From Darkness to Dawn|first=Jamyang|last=Norbu|author-link=Jamyang Norbu|publisher=Phayl}}{{Dead link|date=October 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> Three sets of photographs shot by French soldiers in 1904–05 were the basis for later mythification. The abolition was immediately enforced, and definite: no official sentences of ''lingchi'' were performed in China after April 1905.
Regarding the use of opium, as related in the introduction to Morrison's book, [[Meyrick Hewlett]] insisted that "most Chinese people sentenced to death were given large quantities of opium before execution, and Morrison avers that a charitable person would be permitted to push opium into the mouth of someone dying in agony, thus hastening the moment of decease." At the very least, such tales were deemed credible to British officials in China and other Western observers.
==History== [[File:Martyrdom of Joseph Marchand.jpg|thumb|upright=1|left|Execution of [[Joseph Marchand]] in Vietnam, 1835.]]
''Lingchi'' existed under the earliest emperors,{{citation needed|date=May 2015}} although similar but less cruel tortures were often prescribed instead. Under the reign of [[Qin Er Shi]], the second emperor of the [[Qin dynasty]], multiple tortures were used to punish officials.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Sima|first1=Qian|authorlink1=Sima Qian|title=Records of the Grand Historian|date=91 BCE|location=China|language=Chinese|chapter=87|title-link=Records of the Grand Historian}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Ban|first1=Gu|authorlink1=Ban Gu|title=Book of Han|date=82 CE|language=Chinese|chapter=23|title-link=Book of Han}}</ref>{{clarify|date=March 2015|reason=can't determine if this amounted to lesser torture or worse}} The arbitrary, cruel, and short-lived [[Liu Ziye]] was apt to kill innocent officials by ''lingchi''.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Shen|first1=Yue|authorlink1=Shen Yue|title=Book of Song|date=488 CE|location=China|language=Chinese|chapter=9|title-link=Book of Song}}</ref> [[Emperor Wenxuan of Northern Qi|Gao Yang]] killed only six people by this method,<ref>{{cite book|last1=Li|first1=Baiyao|authorlink1=Li Baiyao|title=Book of Northern Qi|date=636 CE|location=China|language=Chinese|chapter=3|title-link=Book of Northern Qi}}</ref> and [[An Lushan]] killed only one man.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Ouyang|first1=Xiu|authorlink1=Ouyang Xiu|title=New Book of Tang|date=1060 CE|location=China|language=Chinese|chapter=215|title-link=New Book of Tang}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=中國歷史上幾次最著名的凌遲之刑|trans-title=Several of the Most Famous Lingchi Cases in Chinese History|url=http://books.sina.com/artbook/exposure/2008-07-03/ba14878.shtml|date=2008|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090801021147/http://books.sina.com/artbook/exposure/2008-07-03/ba14878.shtml|archive-date=1 August 2009 |website=[[Sina Corp|Sina]]|language=Chinese|access-date=11 October 2015}}</ref> ''Lingchi'' was known in the [[Five Dynasties]] period (907–960 CE); but, in one of the earliest such acts, [[Shi Jingtang]] abolished it.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Xue|first1=Juzheng|authorlink1=Xue Juzheng|title=Old History of the Five Dynasties|date=974 CE|location=China|language=Chinese|chapter=147|title-link=Old History of the Five Dynasties}}</ref> Other rulers continued to use it.
The method was prescribed in the [[Liao dynasty]] law codes,<ref>{{cite book|author=Toqto'a|authorlink1=Toqto'a (Yuan dynasty)|title=History of Liao|date=1344|location=China|language=Chinese|chapter=61|title-link=History of Liao}}</ref> and was sometimes used.<ref>{{cite book|author=Toqto'a|authorlink1=Toqto'a (Yuan dynasty)|title=History of Liao|date=1344|location=China|language=Chinese|chapter=112-114|title-link=History of Liao}}</ref> [[Emperor Tianzuo of Liao|Emperor Tianzuo]] often executed people in this way during his rule.<ref>{{cite book|author=Toqto'a|authorlink1=Toqto'a (Yuan dynasty)|title=History of Liao|date=1344|location=China|language=Chinese|chapter=62|title-link=History of Liao}}</ref> It became more widely used in the [[Song dynasty]] under [[Emperor Renzong of Song|Emperor Renzong]] and [[Emperor Shenzong of Song|Emperor Shenzong]].
Another early proposal for abolishing ''lingchi'' was submitted by [[Lu You]] (1125–1210) in a memorandum to the imperial court of the [[Song dynasty|Southern Song dynasty]]. Lu You's elaborate argument against ''lingchi'' was piously copied and transmitted by generations of scholars, among them influential jurists of all dynasties, until the late Qing dynasty reformist [[Shen Jiaben]] (1840–1913) included it in his 1905 memorandum that obtained the abolition. This anti-''lingchi'' trend coincided with a more general attitude opposed to "cruel and unusual" punishments (such as the exposure of the head) that the Tang dynasty had not included in the canonic table of the [[Five Punishments]], which defined the legal ways of punishing crime. Hence the abolitionist trend is deeply ingrained in the Chinese legal tradition, rather than being purely derived from Western influences.
Under later emperors, ''lingchi'' was reserved for only the most heinous acts, such as treason,<ref>{{cite book|author=Zhang, Tingyu|authorlink1=Zhang Tingyu|title=History of Ming|date=1739|location=China|language=Chinese|chapter=54|title-link=History of Ming}}</ref><ref>[http://www.peacehall.com/cgi-bin/news/gb_display/print_version.cgi?art=/gb/pubvp/2006/03&link=200603030452.shtml 清华大学教授刘书林——中国第一汉奸曾国藩] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070813154736/http://www.peacehall.com/cgi-bin/news/gb_display/print_version.cgi?art=%2Fgb%2Fpubvp%2F2006%2F03&link=200603030452.shtml |date=13 August 2007 }}</ref> a charge often dubious or false, as exemplified by the deaths of [[Liu Jin]], a [[Ming dynasty]] eunuch, and [[Yuan Chonghuan]], a Ming dynasty general. In 1542, ''lingchi'' was inflicted on a group of palace women who had [[Renyin palace rebellion|attempted to assassinate]] the [[Jiajing Emperor]], along with his favourite concubine, [[Consort Duan (Cao)|Consort Duan]]. The bodies of the women were then displayed in public.<ref>{{cite book| editor1=History Office | title=明實錄：明世宗實錄| language=Chinese | trans-title=Veritable Records of the Ming: Veritable Records of Shizong of Ming | url=http://ctext.org/wiki.pl?if=gb&res=309093 | publisher=Ctext | date=1620s | volume=267}}</ref> Reports from Qing dynasty jurists such as Shen Jiaben show that executioners' customs varied, as the regular way to perform this penalty was not specified in detail in the penal code.{{Citation needed|date=July 2007}}
''Lingchi'' was also known in Vietnam, notably being used as the method of execution of the French missionary [[Joseph Marchand]], in 1835, as part of the repression following the unsuccessful [[Lê Văn Khôi revolt]].
An 1858 account by ''[[Harper's Weekly]]'' claimed the martyr [[Auguste Chapdelaine]] was killed by ''lingchi''; in reality he was beaten to death.
As Western countries moved to abolish similar punishments, some Westerners began to focus attention on the methods of execution used in China. As early as 1866, the time when Britain itself moved to abolish its own cruel method of [[hanging, drawing, and quartering]], [[Thomas Francis Wade]], then serving with the British diplomatic mission in China, unsuccessfully urged the abolition of ''lingchi''.
''Lingchi'' remained in the [[Qing dynasty]]'s code of laws for persons convicted of high treason and other serious crimes, but the punishment was abolished as a result of the 1905 revision of the Chinese penal code by Shen Jiaben.<ref>Shen, Jiaben. ''Ji Yi Wen Cun - Zou Yi - Shan Chu Lü Li Nei Zhong Fa Zhe'' (寄簃文存·奏議·刪除律例內重法折).</ref><ref>{{cite book|author=Zhao, Erxun|authorlink1=Zhao Erxun|title=Draft History of Qing|date=1928|location=China|language=Chinese|chapter=118|title-link=Draft History of Qing}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|first1=Jerome|last1=Bourgon|first2=Muriel|last2=Detrie|first3=Regis|last3=Poulet|url=http://turandot.chineselegalculture.org/Essay.php?ID=22|title=Turandot: Chinese Torture / Supplice chinois|publisher=CNRS|date=11 February 2004|accessdate=30 July 2009}}</ref>
==Published accounts== * [[Sir Henry Norman, 1st Baronet|Sir Henry Norman]], ''The People and Politics of the Far East'' (1895). Norman was a widely travelled writer and photographer whose collection is now owned by the [[University of Cambridge]]. Norman gives an eyewitness account of various physical punishments and tortures inflicted in a magistrate's court (''[[yamen]]'') and of the execution by beheading of 15 men. He gives the following graphic account of a ''lingchi'' execution but does not claim to have witnessed such an execution himself. "[The executioner] grasping handfuls from the fleshy parts of the body such as the thighs and breasts slices them away... the limbs are cut off piecemeal at the wrists and ankles, the elbows and knees, shoulders and hips. Finally the condemned is stabbed to the heart and the head is cut off."<ref>[http://turandot.chineselegalculture.org/Textual.php?ID=3&CF=2&Fa=5 Turandot: Chinese Torture/Supplice chinois]. CNRS. Retrieved 20 May 2012.</ref> * [[George Ernest Morrison]], ''An Australian in China'' (1895) differs from some other reports in stating that most ''lingchi'' mutilations are in fact made [[post-mortem]]. Morrison wrote his description based on an account related by a claimed eyewitness: "The prisoner is tied to a rude cross: he is invariably deeply under the influence of [[opium]]. The executioner, standing before him, with a sharp sword makes two quick incisions above the eyebrows, and draws down the portion of skin over each eye, then he makes two more quick incisions across the breast, and in the next moment he pierces the heart, and death is instantaneous. Then he cuts the body in pieces; and the degradation consists in the fragmentary shape in which the prisoner has to appear in heaven."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pratyeka.org/books/australian-in-china/|title=An Australian in China|publisher=Pratyeka|date=25 August 2002|accessdate=30 July 2009}}</ref> * Tienstin ([[Tianjin]]), ''The China Year Book'' (1927), p. 1401, contains contemporary reports from fighting in [[Guangzhou]] (Canton) between the [[Nationalist government|Nanjing government]] and [[Communist Party of China|Communist]] forces. Stories of various atrocities are related, including accounts of ''lingchi''. There is no mention of opium, and these cases appear to be government propaganda. * ''[[The Times]]'', (9 December 1927), a journalist reported from the city of Guangzhou (Canton) that the Communists were targeting Christian priests and that "It was announced that Father Wong was to be publicly executed by the slicing process." * [[George Roerich]], "Trails to Inmost Asia" (1931), p . 119, relates the story of the assassination of Yang Tseng-hsin, Governor of [[Xinjiang|Sinkiang]] in July 1928, by the bodyguard of his foreign minister Fan Yao-han. Fan was seized, and he and his daughter were both executed by ''lingchi'', the minister made to watch his daughter's execution first. Roerich was not an eyewitness to this event, having already returned to India by the date of the execution. * [[George Ryley Scott]], ''History of Torture'' (1940) claims that many were executed this way by the Chinese Communist insurgents; he cites claims made by the Nanking government in 1927. It is perhaps uncertain whether these claims were anti-communist propaganda. Scott also uses the term "the slicing process" and differentiates between the different types of execution in different parts of the country. There is no mention of opium. Riley's book contains a picture of a sliced corpse (with no mark to the heart) that was killed in Guangzhou (Canton) in 1927. It gives no indication of whether the slicing was done post-mortem. Scott claims it was common for the relatives of the condemned to bribe the executioner to kill the condemned before the slicing procedure began.
===Photographs=== The first Western photographs of ''lingchi'' were taken in 1890 by William Arthur Curtis of Kentucky in [[Guangzhou]] (Canton).<ref>{{cite web|first1=Jerome|last1=Bourgon|first2=Muriel|last2=Detrie|first3=Regis|last3=Poulet|url=http://turandot.chineselegalculture.org/Essay.php?ID=3|title=Turandot: Chinese Torture/Supplice chinois|publisher=CNRS|accessdate=30 July 2009}}</ref>
French soldiers stationed in [[Beijing]] had the opportunity to photograph three different ''lingchi'' executions in 1905: * Wang Weiqin (王維勤), a former official who killed two families, executed on 31 October 1904.<ref name=Bourgon2004ID8>{{cite web|editor-last=Bourgon|editor-first=Jérôme|title=Exécution de Wang Weiqin|trans-title=Execution of Wan Weiqin|url=http://turandot.chineselegalculture.org/Event.php?ID=8|date=2004|website=Chinese Torture - Supplices Chinois|publisher=IAO: Institut d'Asie Orientale|language=English, French|accessdate=25 May 2015}}</ref><ref>{{Citation|title=Essay|url=http://turandot.chineselegalculture.org/Essay.php?ID=11}}</ref> * Unknown, reason unknown, possibly a young deranged boy who killed his mother, and was executed in January 1905. Photographs were published in various volumes of Georges Dumas' ''Nouveau traité de psychologie'', 8 vols., Paris, 1930–43<!-- (but not in Dumas' 1923 Traité de psychologie!) -->, and again nominally by Bataille (in fact by Lo Duca), who mistakenly appended abstracts of Fou-tchou-li's executions as related by Carpeaux (see below).<ref>{{Citation|title=The complete set|url=http://turandot.chineselegalculture.org/Event.php?ID=10}}</ref> * Fou-tchou-li or Fuzhuli (符珠哩),<ref>[http://turandot.chineselegalculture.org/Event.php?ID=1 Turandot: Chinese Torture/Supplice chinois]. CNRS. Retrieved 20 May 2012.</ref> a Mongol guard who killed his master, the Prince of the [[Aohan Banner|Aohan]] [[Banners of Inner Mongolia|Banner]] of [[Inner Mongolia]], and who was executed on 10 April 1905; as ''lingchi'' was to be abolished two weeks later, this was presumably the last attested case of ''lingchi'' in Chinese history,<ref>{{cite web|first1=Jerome|last1=Bourgon|first2=Muriel|last2=Detrie|first3=Regis|last3=Poulet|url=http://turandot.chineselegalculture.org/Event.php?ID=1|title=Complete set|publisher=CNRS|accessdate=30 July 2009}}</ref> or said Kang Xiaoba (康小八)<ref>[http://data.tv.sohu.com/movie/data/24054/ 史学研究向下延伸的道路能走多久mm读《狼烟北平》有感]. Sohu. Retrieved 20 May 2012. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110716102545/http://data.tv.sohu.com/movie/data/24054/ |date=16 July 2011 }}</ref> Photographs appeared in books by Matignon (1910), and Carpeaux (1913), the latter claiming (falsely) that he was present.{{Citation needed|date=June 2007}} Carpeaux's narrative was mistakenly, but persistently, associated with photographs published by Dumas and Bataille. Even related to the correct set of photos, Carpeaux's narrative is highly dubious; for instance, an examination of the Chinese judicial archives show that Carpeaux bluntly invented the execution decree. The proclamation is reported to state: "The Mongolian princes demand that the aforesaid Fou-Tchou-Le, guilty of the murder of Prince Ao-Han-Ouan, be burned alive, but the Emperor finds this torture too cruel and condemns Fou-Tchou-Li to slow death by ''leng-tch-e'' (different spelling of ''lingchi'', cutting into pieces)."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.va.com.au/parallel/x1/journal/lmw/coup.html|title=Journal: coup de grâce (#1)|first=Linda Marie|last=Walker|publisher=VA|accessdate=30 July 2009}}</ref>
Photographic material and other sources are available online at the Chinese Torture Database (Iconographic, Historical and Literary Approaches of an Exotic Representation) hosted by the Institut d'Asie Orientale ([[CNRS]], France).<ref>{{cite web|first1=Jerome|last1=Bourgon|first2=Muriel|last2=Detrie|first3=Regis|last3=Poulet|url=http://turandot.chineselegalculture.org/|title=Turandot: Chinese Torture/Supplice chinois|publisher=CNRS|accessdate=30 July 2009}}</ref>
==In popular culture== {{In popular culture|date=August 2017}} Accounts of ''lingchi'' or the extant photographs have inspired or referenced in numerous artistic, literary, and cinematic media. Some works have attempted to put the process in a historical context; others, possibly due to the scarcity of detailed historical information, have attempted to extrapolate the details or present innovations of method that may be products of an author's creative license. Some of these descriptions may have influenced modern public perceptions of the historic practice.
===Non-fiction=== [[Susan Sontag]] mentions the 1905 case in ''Regarding the Pain of Others'' (2003). One reviewer wrote that though Sontag includes no photographs in her book – a volume about photography – "she does tantalisingly describe a photograph that obsessed the philosopher [[Georges Bataille]], in which a Chinese criminal, while being chopped up and slowly [[flaying|flayed]] by executioners, rolls his eyes heavenwards in [[transcendence (philosophy)|transcendent]] bliss."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://books.guardian.co.uk/reviews/politicsphilosophyandsociety/0%2C6121%2C1011239%2C00.html|title=Observer review: Regarding the Pain of Others by Susan Sontag|publisher=The Guardian|date=3 August 2003|accessdate=30 July 2009|location=London|first=Peter|last=Conrad}}</ref>
The philosopher [[Georges Bataille]] wrote about ''lingchi'' in ''L'expérience intérieure'' (1943) and in ''Le coupable'' (1944). He included five pictures in his ''The Tears of Eros'' (1961; translated into English and published by [[City Lights Bookstore|City Lights]] in 1989).<ref>{{Citation|url=http://www.jcrt.org/archives/04.3/york.pdf|first=David|last=York|title=Flesh And Consciousness: George Bataille and the Dionysian|journal=JCRT|date=August 2003}}.</ref> Historians [[Timothy Brook (historian)|Timothy Brook]], Jérome Bourgon and Gregory Blue, criticised Bataille for his language, mistakes and dubious content.<ref>{{cite web|first1=Jerome|last1=Bourgon|first2=Muriel|last2=Detrie|first3=Regis|last3=Poulet|url=http://turandot.chineselegalculture.org/Essay.php?ID=27|title=Turandot: Chinese Torture/Supplice chinois|publisher=CNRS|accessdate=30 July 2009}}.</ref><ref>{{Citation|chapter=6. George Bataille's Interpretation|author1-link=Timothy Brook (historian)|first1=Timothy|last1=Brook|first2=Jérome|last2=Bourgon|first3=Gregory|last3=Blue|title=Death by a Thousand Cuts|place=Cambridge, MA|publisher=Harvard University Press|year=2008|pages=222–42|title-link=Death by a Thousand Cuts (book)}}.</ref>
===Literature=== The "death by a thousand cuts" with reference to China is also mentioned in [[Malcolm Bosse]]'s novel ''The Examination'', [[Amy Tan]]'s novel ''[[The Joy Luck Club (novel)|The Joy Luck Club]]'', and [[Robert van Gulik]]'s ''[[Judge Dee]]'' novels. The 1905 photos are mentioned in [[Thomas Harris]]' novel ''[[Hannibal (Harris novel)|Hannibal]]''<ref>{{Citation|url=http://hannibal.hannotations.com/hannibal1.html|title=Hannibal|chapter=Section I|publisher=Hannotations|accessdate=30 July 2009}}</ref> and in [[Julio Cortázar]]'s novel ''[[Hopscotch (Cortázar novel)|Hopscotch]]''.
===Film=== Inspired by the 1905 photos, Chinese artist Chen Chien-jen created a 25-minute film called ''Lingchi'', which has generated some controversy.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://icwirral.icnetwork.co.uk/entertainment/newsandreviews/tm_objectid=15700731&method=full&siteid=50061&headline=could-you-look-away-from-the-death-of-a-thousand-cuts--name_page.html |title=WirralNews |publisher=IC network |accessdate=30 July 2009 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060317122730/http://icwirral.icnetwork.co.uk/entertainment/newsandreviews/tm_objectid%3D15700731%26method%3Dfull%26siteid%3D50061%26headline%3Dcould-you-look-away-from-the-death-of-a-thousand-cuts--name_page.html |archive-date=17 March 2006 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
A scene of Lingchi also appeared on the film [[The Sand Pebbles (film)]].
==See also== * ''[[Death by a Thousand Cuts (book)|Death by a Thousand Cuts]]'' – a 2008 book that examines the practice of ''lingchi'' * [[Scaphism]] – a similarly slow form of torturous execution * [[Waist chop]]
==Notes== {{Reflist|30em}}
==References== {{commons category|Lingchi}} <!---broken link disabled*{{Cite web|url=http://www.quinzaine-litteraire.net/lmacCollections.php?id=407&PHPSESSID=ca1d15bd5a04e9a91d43d4f1267addbf|first=Jerome|last=Bourgon|title=Supplices chinois|language=French|publisher=Bruxelles: La maison d'à côté|accessdate=20 September 2010}}--> <!---broken link disabled*{{Cite web|url=http://www.hup.harvard.edu/catalog/BRODEA.html|title=Death by a Thousand Cuts|publisher=Harvard University Press|accessdate=20 September 2010}}--> * {{cite book |last1=Brook |first1=Timothy |authorlink=Timothy Brook |last2=Bourgon |first2=Jérôme |last3=Blue |first3=Gregory |title=Death by a Thousand Cuts |date=2008 |location=Cambridge, MA |publisher=Harvard University Press |isbn=978-0-674-02773-2|title-link=Death by a Thousand Cuts (book) }} * {{cite journal |last=Bourgon |first=Jérôme |title=Abolishing 'Cruel Punishments': A Reappraisal of the Chinese Roots and Long-Term Efficiency of the in Legal Reforms |journal=[[Modern Asian Studies]] |volume=37 |issue=4 |year=2003 |pages=851–62 |doi=10.1017/S0026749X03004050 }}

'''Mesures usuelles''' ({{IPA-fr|məzyʁ yzɥɛl}}, ''customary measurements'') were a system of [[measurement]] introduced by [[Napoleon I of France|Napoleon I]] in 1812 to act as compromise between the [[SI|metric system]] and traditional measurements. The system was restricted to use in the retail industry and continued in use until 1839.
==Rationale behind the new system== [[File:Napoleon Groot.jpg|150px|thumb|left|The ''ordinary measures'' were introduced by [[Napoleon I of France|Napoleon I]] in 1812]] In the five years immediately before the [[French First Republic]] introduced the [[metric system]], every effort was made to make the citizens aware of the upcoming changes and to prepare them for it.<ref name="Alder"/> The administration distributed tens of thousands of educational pamphlets, private enterprise produced educational games, guides, almanacs and conversion aids, and metre standards were built into the walls of prominent buildings around Paris.<ref name="Alder"/> The introduction was phased by district over the next few years, with Paris being the first district to change. The government also realised that the people would need metre rulers, but they had only provided 25,000 of the 500,000 rulers needed in Paris as late as one month after the metre became the sole legal unit of measure.<ref name="Alder">{{cite book |title = The Measure of all Things - The Seven-Year-Odyssey that Transformed the World |last= Alder |first= Ken |year= 2002 |publisher= Abacus |location= London |isbn=0-349-11507-9}}</ref> To compensate, the government introduced incentives for the mass-production of rulers. Paris police reported widespread flouting of the requirement for merchants to use only the metric system.<ref name="Alder"/> Where the new system was in use, it was abused, with shopkeepers taking the opportunity to round prices up and to give smaller measures.<ref name="Alder"/>
[[image:Louis-Philippe-France.png|150px|thumb|right|The ''Mesures usuelles'' were abolished by Louis-Philippe in 1839]] [[Napoleon I of France|Napoleon I]], the French Emperor, disliked the inconvenience of surrendering the high [[factorization|factorability]] of traditional measures in the name of [[decimal]]isation, and recognized the difficulty of getting it accepted by the populace.<ref>{{cite web |url = https://books.google.com/books?id=cf1BAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA91&dq=je+me+moque+des+divisions+d%C3%A9cimales&cd=1#v=onepage&q=je%20me%20moque%20des%20divisions%20d%C3%A9cimales&f=false |author = Napoleon I |title = Letter to Général Clarke, duc de Feltre |date = 19 December 1809 |work = Correspondance de Napoléon Ier: publiée par ordre de l'empereur Napoléon III. |quote = Je me moque des divisions décimales [I don't care about decimal divisions] |accessdate = 2011-02-10}}</ref> Under the ''décret impérial du 12 février 1812'' (imperial decree of 12 February 1812), he introduced a new system of measurement, the ''mesures usuelles'' or "customary measures", for use in small retail businesses. However, all government, legal and similar works still had to use the metric system and the metric system continued to be taught at all levels of education.<ref name=historique>{{cite web |url = http://www.industrie.gouv.fr/metro/aquoisert/metre.htm |title = Un historique du mètre |language = French |author = Denis Février |publisher = Ministère de l'Economie, des Finances et de l'Industrie |accessdate = 2011-03-10}}</ref><ref>For example the engineering textbook, {{cite book |title = Traité élémentaire de méchanique industrielle |author = Stéphane Flachat |authorlink=Stéphane Flachat |place = Paris |year = 1835 |accessdate = 2011-02-17 |url = https://books.google.com/books?id=ghbWAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA33&lpg=PA33&dq=Puissance+poncelet#v=onepage&q=Puissance%20poncelet&f=false}}</ref>
The [[prototype]]s of the metric unit, the [[kilogram]] and the [[metre]], enabled an immediate standardization of measurement over the whole country, replacing the varying legal measures in different parts of the country, and even more across the whole of Europe. The new ''livre'' (known as the ''livre métrique'') was defined as five hundred [[gram]]s, and the new ''toise'' (''toise métrique'') was defined as two [[metre]]s. Products could be sold in shops under the old names and with the old relationships to one another, but with slightly different absolute sizes. This series of measurements was called ''mesures usuelles''.
Napoleon's decree was revoked during the reign of [[Louis Philippe]] by the ''loi du 4 juillet 1837'' (law of 4 July 1837). This took effect on 1 January 1840, and reinstated the original metric system, thus bringing the system of ''mesures usuelles'' to an end.<ref name=historique/>
==Permitted units== The law authorised the following units of measure:<ref name=H&H>{{cite web |url = https://archive.org/stream/outlinesofevolut00halluoft/outlinesofevolut00halluoft_djvu.txt |title = Outlines of the evolution of weights and measures and the metric system |first1 = William |last1 = Hallock |first2 = Herbert T |last2 = Wade |publisher = The Macmillan Company |year = 1906 |pages = 66–69 |location = London}}</ref>
* {{anchor|pied}} The ''[[toise]]'' (fathom) was defined as two metres and was divided into 6 ''pieds'', or "feet" and 72 ''pouces'' (inches). The ''pouce'' was divided into 12 ''lignes'', or (lines). The ''pied'' and ''pouce'', at approximately 333.3 mm and 27.78 mm, were about 2.6% larger than the previous Parisian measures and 9% larger than their British counterparts. *The ''aune'' ([[ell]]), used to measure cloth, was defined as 120 centimetres, and divided into the ''demi aune'' (half an ell) and the ''tiers aune'' (third of an ell). It was 1.3% larger than ''l’aune de Paris'' (118.48 cm) and 5.0% larger than its English counterpart (45 inches; 114.3 cm).<ref>{{cite web |title = Les poids et mesures sous l’Ancien Régime |language = French |trans-title=The weights and measures of the Ancien Régime |url = http://www.histoire-genealogie.com/spip.php?article396 |author = Thierry Sabot |date = 1 October 2000 |accessdate = 2011-02-10 |publisher = histoire-genealogie}}</ref>
*The [[litre]] was subdivided like an English [[quart]], into ''demis'' (literally, "halves", being the equivalent of a [[pint]] of about sixteen [[fluid ounce]]s), ''quarts'' (literally, "fourths", being the equivalent of a cup of about eight fluid ounces), ''huitièmes'' (literally, "eighths") and ''seizièmes'' (literally, "sixteenths", of about two fluid ounces). *The ''boisseau'', ([[bushel]]), was redefined as being an eighth of a hectolitre and with associated measures ''double-boisseau'', ''demi-boisseau'' and ''quart-boisseau'' (double, half and quarter bushels respectively). The original ''boisseau'', like the English bushel, varied depending on the ''commodity for which'' it was used, as well as the ''region where'' it was used. *The ''livre'', ([[Pound (mass)|pound]]), was defined as 500 grams, divided into 16 ''onces'', (ounces), each ''once'' being divided into 8 ''gros''. Each gros being thought of as being composed of 72 ''grains'', whose name is the same as in English. Hence, the livre was 9216 ''grains''.<ref name=Europa1842/> The ''livre'' and ''once'' were about 10% larger than their English counterparts, while the ''grain'' was 17% less than its English counterpart. It can be noted that the metric livre, although not legal, is still commonly used in daily life in France in the 21st century.
The ''mesures usuelles'' did not include any units of length greater than the ''toise'' - the ''[[myriamètre]]'' (10 km) remaining in use throughout this period.<ref name="Europa1842">{{cite web |url=http://home.fonline.de/fo0126/geschichte/groessen/mas10.htm |title=Königreich Frankreich |language=German |trans-title=Kingdom of France |work=''Amtliche Maßeinheiten in Europa 1842'' [Official units of measure in Europe 1842] |first=Wolfgang |last=Appell |date=2009-09-16 |orig-year=2002 |postscript= (Website based on ''Alte Meß- und Währungssysteme aus dem deutschen Sprachgebiet'', {{ISBN|3-7686-1036-5}}.) |accessdate=2011-02-10 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111005102232/http://home.fonline.de/fo0126/geschichte/groessen/mas10.htm |archive-date=2011-10-05 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
== See also == {{div col|small=yes|colwidth=20em}} * [[French units of measurement]] * [[History of measurement]] * [[History of the metric system]] * [[International System of Units]] * [[List of unusual units of measurement]] * [[Metric system]] * [[Systems of measurement]] * [[Units of measurement]] {{div col end}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox Website |name =Mouchette.org |screenshot =Mouchette.png |screenshot_size =300px |caption =The mouchette.org homepage |url =http://www.mouchette.org |commercial = |type =Internet art |language =English/French |owner =Martine Neddam |author ="Mouchette"(pseudonym) for Martine Neddam |launch date ={{Start date|1996}} |current status =active }} '''''Mouchette.org''''' is an interactive website created in 1996 by a [[pseudonym]]ous character, an Amsterdam-based artist who calls herself "Mouchette". With her innocent salutation and claims to be "nearly thirteen" {{cite web |url=http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m0268/is_/ai_75914220 |title=Immaterial Girl – website based on Mouchette film character – Brief Article |accessdate=2008-05-01 |author=Jane Harris |date=May 2001 |work= |publisher=ArtForum}}{{dead link|date=July 2017}} greeting the visitor from the introduction page, what initially appears as a personal website of a pre-pubescent female artist evolves into darker themes in the subsequent pages. Mouchette is loosely based on a 1937 book by [[Georges Bernanos]] and the 1967 [[Robert Bresson]] movie, ''[[Mouchette]]''. The storyline is about a French teenager who commits suicide after she is raped. An online quiz comparing the "Neo-Mouchette"{{cite book |last=Green |first=Rachel |title=Internet Art |origyear= |month= |url= |format= |series= |year=2004 |publisher=Thames & Hudson Ltd. |location= London |isbn=0-500-20376-8 |pages=115}} to the movie angered Bresson's widow, so she threatened a lawsuit against the artist behind the project. The quiz was taken down after that incident.{{cite web |url=http://mouchette.org/film/quiz.html |title=SACD letter |accessdate=2008-04-29 |website=Mouchette.org}}{{cite journal |last=Sant |first=Toni |authorlink=Toni Sant |author2=Santorineos, Manthos |year=2005 |title=Rape, Murder and Suicide Are Easier When You Use a Keyboard Shortcut: Mouchette, an On-Line Virtual Character |journal=Leonardo |volume=38 |issue=3 |pages=203–207 |url=http://leonardo.info/ |accessdate=2008-04-25 |quote= |doi=10.1162/0024094054028921 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080509070115/http://www.leonardo.info/ |archivedate=2008-05-09 |df= }} The creator of the website has been a closely guarded secret, though the piece has somewhat recently been claimed by artist [[Martine Neddam]]. While the use of taboo subject matters are what initially "provokes heated reactions", the manipulation of cyber identity and the ability of the creator to maintain anonymity for so long are the significant reasons this website has garnered its "international reputation" in the [[Internet art]] community. ==Summary and themes== {{cquote|My name is Mouchette
I live in Amsterdam
I am nearly 13 years old
I am an artist...}} This simple and "deceptively innocent"{{cite book |title=New Media Art |last=Tribe |first=Mark |author2=Jana, Reena |year=2007 |url= https://wiki.brown.edu/confluence/display/MarkTribe/New+Media+Art |chapter=Mouchette |chapterurl=https://wiki.brown.edu/confluence/display/MarkTribe/Mouchette |publisher=Taschen |location=Germany |isbn=978-3-8228-3041-3 |pages=66–67 }} introduction, which appears next to a portrait of a "sad eyed" adolescent girl on the main page with a floral background, is in stark contrast to the complexity of the rest of the site. Consisting "of various secret links, electronic interactive texts, and poems that reveal the multiple faces of the artist, along with her fears and obsessions",{{cite web|url=http://www.dartmouth.edu/~arthist/content/websites/website4/website4.html|title=Mouchette: "Interactivity and Accountability" |accessdate=2008-05-01 }} participants of the website are often left wondering whether "a website this sophisticated [could] really be the work of a 13 year old girl". ===Suicide, death, and violence=== Just like the film ''[[Mouchette]]'', one of the many themes running throughout Mouchette.org is the idea of death. The recurring image of a fly is present on many of the pages. The word "mouchette" translates into English as "little fly". The comparable lives between the Mouchettes – the fly and the girl – are intersected when it revolves around the death of the fly. On one page, Mouchette refers to herself as the fly and blames the web visitor for killing her when he/she pressed a button on the previous webpage.{{cite web |url=http://mouchette.org/fly/dead.html |title=Mouchette.org: "dead fly" |accessdate=2008-04-29 }} On another page, somber music plays as the phrase "Lullaby for a dead fly" is shown on the screen.{{cite web |url=http://mouchette.org/fly/flies.html |title=Mouchette.org: "Lullaby for a dead fly" |accessdate=2008-04-29 }} As stated in ''Internet Art'', "in early iterations of the site, the virtual persona Mouchette was obsessed with suicide". One page asks the viewer on what they think the best way to kill yourself when you’re under 13.{{cite web |url=http://mouchette.org/suicide/suikit.html |title=Mouchette.org: "Suicide Kit" |accessdate=2008-04-29}} On a page entitled m.org.ue, an image of feet is shown, with one foot wearing a toe tag, while ghostly music plays.{{cite web |url=http://mouchette.org/m.org.ue/index.html |title=Mouchette.org: "m.org.ue" |accessdate=2008-04-29}} When a link called "meet my parent" is clicked, it directs to a page that has scanned images of meat, with the words "Papa" and "Maman" carved in it.{{cite web |url=http://mouchette.org/flesh/pere.html |title=Mouchette.org: "my father" |accessdate=2008-04-29}} On another page, an image of a cat violently shakes on the screen while sounds of screaming are playing; the viewer is asked to kill this cat.{{cite web |url=http://mouchette.org/cat/index.html |title=Mouchette.org: "Kll that cat" |accessdate=2008-04-29}} ===Sex=== "Sexually suggestive" themes are present throughout the site. One the opening page of the section named "***digital flesh&blood***" the background image is of a close up of a young girl’s face, sticking out her tongue. The text accompanying this image reads: "Want to know what my tongue tastes like? Try it on your screen and tell me."{{cite web |url=http://mouchette.org/flesh/tong.html |title=Mouchette.org:"***digital flesh&blood***" |accessdate=2008-04-29}} Another page, titled "touché", has a completely black background, with tiny white words scattered in different sections of the page. As the pointer scrolls over specific points on the page, sounds of a woman gasping are activated.{{cite web |url=http://mouchette.org/secret/secret.html |title=Mouchette.org: "touché" |accessdate=2008-04-29}} Many pages of this website have interactive web forms that include multiple-choice questions asking your email address. Days or weeks later the viewer might get unexpected flirtatious email messages from Mouchette. ===Manipulating identity=== Participants are given the opportunity to "become Mouchette", when they become a member of the "Mouchette Network". Members can "create true Mouchette webpages" and are given "a unique opportunity to become a great artist."{{cite web |url=http://www.edit.mouchette.org/ |title=Mouchette.org: Become Mouchette |accessdate=2008-04-29}} The interactive questionnaires often will ask you to post your name and email address if you answer one of the questions. But the anonymity of the creator and the unsettling topics makes a participant wonder how seriously he/she should answer the questions, including question about their name and identity. Days/weeks later, participants will get a random email from Mouchette. This will often be unsettling because it's random and unexpected, leaving the participant to question their identity/decision to input personal information of the website. The website's exploration of manipulating identity has been compared to conceptual photographer, [[Cindy Sherman]]. ==Criticism and controversy== {{Criticism section|date=November 2010}} With its taboo subject matter, Mouchette.org has "provoked heated reaction" in the art community. An interactive forum allows participants to state why they hate Mouchette. In an early version of Mouchette.org, there was a quiz comparing web persona Mouchette and the lead character in the [[Robert Bresson|Bresson]] film ''[[Mouchette]]''. Images taken from the film were used in this quiz. In 2002, the Robert Bresson estate "threatened legal action against the artist" responsible for Mouchette.org. According to [[Toni Sant]], "This case brought the online piece to the attention of many who might have overlooked it in the plethora of Net Art that has emerged over the past few years". In a letter from the [[SACD (Société des Auteurs et Compositeurs Dramatiques)]] (the French Society of Dramatic Authors and Composers) addressed to the creator of Mouchette.org, it states that Bresson's widow "demands that all reference to the film ''Mouchette''...be eliminated from your website." According to Sant, "this copyright issue raises the question of ownership over fictional identities...and raises issues of originality and ownership." After the forced removal of the quiz from Mouchette.org, "as a protest, a growing network of websites are hosting copies of this work which is no longer allowed to be shown on http://mouchette.org" The distributor of the quiz blames the "narrow-mindedness of the heir of the copyright" for censoring "a work which is an homage celebrating the source of its inspiration."{{cite web |url=http://drivedrive.com/mouchette/censored.html |title=Mouchette.org: "Censored" |accessdate=2008-04-28}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://mouchette.org mouchette.org] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20080502034832/http://www.ciac.ca/magazine/archives/no_13/en/oeuvres.html Centre International D'Art Contemporain de Montreal: Web Projects no.13] * [http://www.mediamatic.net/artefact-29855-en.html Mediamatic: Swap, Use & Abuse your identity] * [http://rhizome.org/editorial/news/story.php?timestamp=20021015|Rhizome News: A Tale of Two Mouchettes] {{dead link|date=July 2017}} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20030219111000/http://www.turbulence.org/curators/media/ Turbulence.org: New Media, New Narrative] * [http://www.franklinfurnace.org/grants/artists_updates/mouchette/sant_tony_article.pdf Mouchette: with Manthos Santorineos]{{dead link|date=May 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} Introduction by [[Toni Sant]] * http://www.digitalarti.com/en/video/wj_spots1_42_martine_neddam_aka_mouchette ===Recent art exhibits=== *November 2011, [http://www.year01.com/mediummassage "Medium_Massage 2.0 :: an infinite inventory"], [http://www.year01.com/ Year Zero One + CONTACT Gallery], Toronto, Canada. *September 2007, [http://knotenpunkte.net/kp-en/artist7.html "To be or not to be Mouchette"], [http://www.kunstmuseum-siegen.de/ Museum of Contemporary Art], Siegen, Germany. *March 2006, [https://web.archive.org/web/20081016054245/http://www.akimbo.biz/events/?id=3082&day=23&month=3 DORKBOT-TORONTO], [http://www.interaccess.org/ InterAccess Electronic Media Arts Centre], Toronto, Ontario. *May 2005, [https://web.archive.org/web/20110723130154/http://www.flashfestival.net/2005/index.php?rub=mouchette Flash Festival "intime*10"], [http://www.centrepompidou.fr/Pompidou/Accueil.nsf/Document/HomePage?OpenDocument&L=2 Centre Pompidou], Paris, France. *March 2004, [https://web.archive.org/web/20081016081858/http://www.usc.edu/dept/matrix/aim/aimv/entries3.htm SYZYGY (The Human Remix)], [https://web.archive.org/web/20080724021155/http://www.usc.edu/dept/matrix/aim/aimv/ Art in Motion Festival], [[University of Southern California]], California, USA {{DEFAULTSORT:Mouchette.Org}} {{COI|date=September 2017}} {{primary sources|date=September 2017}} {{Infobox company | homepage = https://www.onelogin.com | type = [[Private company]] | industry = Cloud computing | location = San Francisco, CA | name = OneLogin | logo = OneLogin logo.svg | foundation = 2009 | founders = Thomas Pedersen, Christian Pedersen }}
'''OneLogin, Inc.''' is a cloud-based [[identity and access management]] (IAM) provider focused on selling to businesses and other organizations. The company's goals are to use IAM to secure user access to applications and devices, reduce IT time on user onboarding and offboarding, and increase end user productivity through [[single sign-on]] (SSO).
OneLogin's Open Source SAML Toolkits are now used by over 300 app vendors and over 70 SaaS vendors to make their apps more secure. OneLogin integrates with multiple cloud applications, most recently Namely, Workplace by Facebook and RemedyForce.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.onelogin.com/company/press/press-releases/onelogin-pioneers-first-ever-hr-driven-identity-integration-with-namely|title=(Press Release) OneLogin Pioneers First-Ever HR-driven Identity Integration with Namely - OneLogin|last=|first=|date=|website=OneLogin|language=en-US|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-09-26}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.onelogin.com/company/press/press-releases/onelogin-announces-integration-partnership-with-workplace-by-facebook|title=(Press Release) OneLogin Announces Integration Partnership with Workplace by Facebook - OneLogin|last=|first=|date=|website=OneLogin|language=en-US|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-09-26}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.onelogin.com/blog/how-to-take-the-pain-out-of-it-service-management|title=(Press Release) How to take the Pain out of IT Service Management|last=|first=|date=|website=OneLogin|language=en-US|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-09-26}}</ref>
==History==
OneLogin was founded in 2009 in San Francisco by Thomas and Christian Pedersen. The brothers were involved with the on-demand help desk application, [[Zendesk]], before launching OneLogin. Through their interactions with Zendesk customers, the founders realized that companies were encountering security and productivity challenges moving into the cloud. This is where the idea came to build an identity and access management solution that was secure and easy to use. OneLogin officially launched in 2010.<ref name="FCV">{{cite web|last1=Kepes|first1=Ben|title=From Copenhagen To The Valley - OneLogin's Journey|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/benkepes/2013/10/30/from-copenhagen-to-the-valley-onelogins-journey/#486955b744b8|website=Forbes|accessdate=3 August 2017}}</ref> In August 2017, OneLogin appointed Brad Brooks as chief executive officer.<ref name="GNW">{{cite web|url=https://globenewswire.com/news-release/2017/08/08/1081741/0/en/OneLogin-Appoints-Brad-Brooks-as-Chief-Executive-Officer.html|title=(Press Release) OneLogin Appoints Brad Brooks as Chief Executive Officer|last=|first=|date=|website=GlobeNewsWire|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=11 August 2017}}</ref>
==Products==
OneLogin's product line-up includes the following: * Single Sign-On * Cloud Directory * User Provisioning * Multi-factor Authentication (MFA) * Adaptive Authentication * Mobile Identity Management * Virtual LDAP * Cloud RADIUS * Desktop Authentication * Web Access Management (WAM)
==Customers==
OneLogin customers use the company's service to manage millions of user identities in dozens of countries. The company serves customers from a range of industries including technology, education, retail, financial services, manufacturing, media, health and life sciences, and services. Some representative customers of OneLogin include [[Steelcase]], [[Pinterest]], [[Dell]] Services, [[San Jose Unified School District]], [[Practice Fusion]], [[Acuris]], [[Fairfax Media]], Sonnen, [[Kreditech]], [[Berklee College of Music]], and [[Berwin Leighton Paisner]].<ref name="OLCS">{{cite web|url=https://www.onelogin.com/customers/customer-stories|title=(Press Release) OneLogin Customers|last=|first=|date=|website=Customer Stories|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=3 August 2017}}</ref>
==Integrations and Partnerships==
The OneLogin API provides endpoints for SAML, OpenID Connect, SCIM, and OAuth. There are also SAML Toolkits for [[Java (programming language)|Java]], [[Python (programming language)|Python]], [[Ruby (programming language)|Ruby]], and [[PHP]], made available on the company's public [[GitHub]] repositories. These toolkits are actively developed by dozens of contributors. These SAML toolkits have been downloaded more than three million times.<ref name="Rubygems">{{cite web|title=ruby-saml|url=https://rubygems.org/gems/ruby-saml/|website=RubyGems.org|accessdate=10 August 2017}}</ref>
OneLogin provides [[single sign-on]] for cloud applications including Microsoft [[Office 365]], Google [[G Suite]], [[Salesforce.com]], [[Amazon Web Services]], [[ServiceNow]], and [[Workplace by Facebook]]. Users may sign in to its single sign-on service using their credentials from [[Google]], [[Facebook]], [[LinkedIn]], and [[Twitter]]. The company's offerings also integrate with the following directories: [[Active Directory]], [[Active Directory Federation Services|ADFS]], [[LDAP]], [[Google]] [[G Suite]] Directory, [[Workday, Inc.|Workday]], Ultimate Software UltiPro, and [[Namely (company)|Namely]].<ref name="App Catalog">{{cite web|url=https://support.onelogin.com/hc/en-us/articles/202361810-App-Catalog|title=(Press Release) App Catalog|last=|first=|date=|website=OneLogin App Catalog|publisher=OneLogin|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=11 August 2017}}</ref> OneLogin sends data to Security Information and Event Management (SIEM) systems, including Splunk, [[Sumo Logic]], and ELK/Elastic.<ref name="SocialSignIn">{{cite web|url=https://support.onelogin.com/hc/en-us/articles/208335063-Social-Sign-in|title=(Press Release) Social Sign-In|last=|first=|date=|website=Social Sign-In|publisher=OneLogin|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=11 August 2017}}</ref>
OneLogin Protect, a mobile application for multi-factor authentication, runs on [[iOS]] and [[Android (operating system)|Android]] devices. OneLogin integrates with third-party MFA providers Duo Security, [[Google Authenticator]], RSA SecurID, [[Symantec]] VIP Access, [[Yubico]] Yubikey, [[Gemalto]] SafeNet, Swivel Pinsafe, VASCO DIGIPASS and IDENTIKEY, and FireID Security. OneLogin Desktop Authentication runs on [[Windows]] and [[MacOS|Mac]] computers.<ref name="OLMFA2">{{cite web|url=https://support.onelogin.com/hc/en-us/articles/202123454-Adding-Multi-Factor-Authentication-|title=(Press Release) Adding Multi-Factor Authentication|last=|first=|date=|website=Adding Multi-Factor Authentication|publisher=OneLogin|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=11 August 2017}}</ref>
OneLogin SSO Browser Extensions run on Google Chrome, Microsoft Edge and Internet Explorer, Safari, and Firefox. OneLogin integrates with RADIUS to authenticate into network appliances including WiFi access points and VPN servers, including those from Cisco Meraki and Juniper.<ref name="Brext">{{cite web|url=https://support.onelogin.com/hc/en-us/articles/201175244-OneLogin-Browser-Extensions|title=(Press Release) OneLogin Browser Extensions|last=|first=|date=|website=OneLogin Browser Extensions|publisher=OneLogin|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=11 August 2017}}</ref> OneLogin Web Access Management integrates with Apache, Microsoft IIS, and Tomcat. OneLogin integrates with [[cloud access security broker]]s (CASBs) Cisco Cloudlock, Skyhigh, and [[Bitglass]].<ref name="ISVP">{{cite web|title=OneLogin ISV Partners|url=https://www.onelogin.com/partners/isv-partners|website=OneLogin ISV Partners|publisher=OneLogin|accessdate=11 August 2017}}</ref>
In September 2016, OneLogin announced a partnership with [[Deutsche Telekom]]’s T-Systems to resell OneLogin within the European Union (EU).<ref name="OLDT">{{cite web|url=https://www.onelogin.com/company/press/press-releases/onelogin-signs-contract-with-deutsche-telekom-t-systems|title=(Press Release) OneLogin Signs Contract with Deutsche Telekom's T-Systems|last=|first=|date=|website=OneLogin Signs Contract with Deutsche Telekom’s T-Systems|publisher=OneLogin|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=11 August 2017}}</ref>
==Funding==
OneLogin is backed by the venture firms [[Charles River Ventures]], The [[Social Capital]], and [[Scale Venture Partners]]. Its venture funding includes:<ref name="CB">{{cite web|title=OneLogin, Inc.|url=https://www.crunchbase.com/organization/onelogin#/entity|website=CrunchBase|publisher=CrunchBase|accessdate=11 August 2017}}</ref> * $4.7M Series A in June 2010 * $13M Series B in October 2013 * $25M Series C in December 2014 * $10M Series C May 2017 * $22.5M Series C in June 2018
==Acquisitions==
In December 2015, OneLogin acquired San Diego-based Cafésoft, a provider of on-premise [[Web Access Management]] (WAM) software. The technology enables OneLogin to extend Single Sign-on to applications running on-premises.<ref name="OLACS">{{cite web|url=https://www.onelogin.com/blog/onelogin-acquires-cafesoft-why-its-great-for-customers-and-partners|title=(Press Release) OneLogin Acquires Cafesoft|last=|first=|date=|website=OneLogin|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=11 August 2017}}</ref>
In June 2016, OneLogin acquired Santa Clara, California-based Portadi, a cloud-based password management tool. The technology enables OneLogin to automatically populate customer's OneLogin single sign-on portals with applications as employees manually sign into them.<ref name="OLAPADI">{{cite web|url=https://www.onelogin.com/company/press/press-releases/onelogin-acquires-portadi-to-boost-password-management-in-the-enterprise|title=(Press Release) OneLogin Acquires Portandi|last=|first=|date=|website=OneLogin|publisher=OneLogin|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=11 August 2017}}</ref>
In November 2016, OneLogin acquired London-based Sphere Secure Workspace, a software vendor with container technology that runs on mobile devices.<ref name="SPHERE">{{cite web|url=https://www.onelogin.com/blog/a-better-way-to-secure-mobile-apps|title=(Press Release) OneLogin acquires Sphere|last=|first=|date=|website=OneLogin|publisher=OneLogin|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=11 August 2017}}</ref>
In June 2017, OneLogin acquired Auckland, New Zealand-based ThisData, a developer-focused cloud security company specializing in account takeover detection. The technology has been used to enable OneLogin's adaptive authentication solution, which uses machine learning to intelligently score the risk of each login attempt, and challenges users making high-risk logins to use an additional authentication factor.<ref name="ThisData">{{cite web|title=Why ThisData has Joined with OneLogin|url=https://www.onelogin.com/blog/why-thisdata-has-joined-with-onelogin|website=OneLogin|publisher=OneLogin|accessdate=11 August 2017}}</ref>
==Awards and Recognition==
In May 2015, [[Forrester Research]] ranked OneLogin as the top vendor in the Forrester Wave for Cloud Identity & Access Management.<ref name="Forrester2015">{{cite web|url=http://get.onelogin.com/2015ForresterWave.html|title=(Press Release) OneLogin Receives Highest Score Among All Vendors in Current Offering Category|last=|first=|date=|website=Onelogin|publisher=Forrester|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=11 August 2017}}</ref>
In December 2015, OneLogin was named a "Best Place to Work" by Glassdoor.<ref name="GD2015">{{cite web|url=https://www.onelogin.com/blog/onelogin-awarded-by-glassdoor-best-places-to-work-2016|title=(Press Release) Onelogin Awarded by Glassdoor: "Best Places to Work 2016"|last=|first=|date=|website=OneLogin|publisher=OneLogin|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=11 August 2017}}</ref>
In January 2016, OneLogin was ranked 28th on Deloitte's Technology Fast 500, a ranking of the 500 fastest growing technology, media, telecommunications, life sciences and energy tech companies in North America.<ref name="Fast500">{{cite web|url=https://www.onelogin.com/company/press/press-releases/onelogin-ranked-as-number-28th-fastest-growing-company-in-north-america-on-deloittes-2015-technology-fast-500|title=(Press Release) OneLogin Ranked as The 28th Fastest Growing Company in North America on Deloitte’s 2015 Technology Fast 500|last=|first=|date=|website=OneLogin|publisher=OneLogin|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=11 August 2017}}</ref>
In March 2016, OneLogin was named to the "Fast 50" privately held Internet security, networking, and storage companies by JMP Securities LLC.<ref name="Fast50">{{cite web|url=https://www.onelogin.com/company/press/press-releases/onelogin-named-jmp-securities-fast-50-list-hottest-privately-held-companies|title=(Press Release) OneLogin Named to JMP Securities Fast 50 List of Hottest Privately Held Companies|last=|first=|date=|website=OneLogin|publisher=OneLogin|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=11 August 2017}}</ref>
OneLogin has been named a "Top Workplace" by the Bay Area News Group and the Great Place to Work series.<ref name="issuu">{{cite web|title=Bay Area News Group Top Workplaces 2016|url=https://issuu.com/mngtargetedproducts/docs/0626twp2016|website=issuu|publisher=issuu|accessdate=11 August 2017}}</ref>
In July 2017, [[Gartner]] Peer Insights ranked OneLogin #1 among Access Management providers. The company has been mentioned in [[USA Today]], [[TechCrunch]], [[The Wall Street Journal]], [[Forbes]], [[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]], [[Marketwatch]], [[The Atlantic]], and [[Fortune (magazine)|Fortune]].
==Certifications==
OneLogin maintains the following certifications:<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.onelogin.com/compliance|title=(Press Release) Compliance|last=|first=|date=|website=Compliance|publisher=OneLogin|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=11 August 2017}}</ref> * SOC 2 Type 2 * SOC 1 Type 2 * ISO 27017:2015 * ISO 27018:2014 * ISO 20001:2013 * Skyhigh Enterprise-Ready * CSA STAR * TRUSTe Certified Privacy * U.S. Privacy Shield * EU Model Contract Clauses
OneLogin has published the scope of its compliance with: * [[HIPAA]] * [[FFIEC]] / [[GLBA]] * [[NIST Cybersecurity Framework]] * [[FERPA]] * [[G-Cloud]] * [[GDPR]]
==Availability==
OneLogin reports on the current and historic availability of its service at onelogin.com/trust, with backup availability status pages at onelogin.status.io and onelogineu.status.io. OneLogin runs in multiple [[Amazon Web Services]] (AWS) datacenters in the US, as well as in AWS Dublin and AWS Frankfurt.<ref name="OLTRUST">{{cite web|url=https://www.onelogin.com/why-onelogin/trust|title=(Press Release) Availability Status|last=|first=|date=|website=OneLogin|publisher=OneLogin|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=11 August 2017}}</ref>
OneLogin remained available and performant during the October 2016 attack on Dyn, a major provider of DNS services, which brought down many websites, including Spotify, Twitter, Reddit, and The New York Times, in part by using redundant DNS providers.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.onelogin.com/blog/how-onelogin-maintained-100-percent-uptime-during-the-dyn-ddos-attack|title=(Press Release) How OneLogin maintained 100% uptime during the Dyn DDoS attack|last=|first=|date=|website=OneLogin|publisher=OneLogin|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=11 August 2017}}</ref>
==Security==
OneLogin regularly performs penetration tests and network scans, anti-phishing programs, and runs a bug bounty program and vulnerability disclosure program.<ref name="OLCompliance">{{cite web|url=https://www.onelogin.com/compliance/|title=(Press Release) OneLogin Compliance Initiatives|last=|first=|date=|website=OneLogin|publisher=OneLogin|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=11 August 2017}}</ref>
''OneLogin Security Breach, August 2016''
In August 2016, OneLogin reported that "an unauthorised user gained access to one of our standalone systems, which we use for log storage and analytics.". The single user accessed the service for a month or more, and may have been able to see Secure Notes unencrypted. To remediate, OneLogin fixed the cleartext logging bug, locked down access to the log management system, and reset passwords.<ref name="OLBreach1">{{cite web|url=https://www.onelogin.com/blog/august-2016-incident|title=(Press Release) August 2016 Incident|last=|first=|date=|website=OneLogin|publisher=OneLogin|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=11 August 2017}}</ref>
''OneLogin Security Breach, May 2017''
On May 31, 2017, OneLogin detected and stopped unauthorized access in their US data region. According to a OneLogin blog post on the breach, "a threat actor used one of our AWS keys to gain access to our AWS platform via an API from an intermediate host with another, smaller service provider in the US."<ref name="Breach2">{{cite web|url=https://www.onelogin.com/blog/may-31-2017-security-incident|title=(Press Release) May 31, 2017 Security Incident|last=|first=|date=|website=OneLogin|publisher=OneLogin|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=11 August 2017}}</ref>
OneLogin staff detected the intrusion in seven hours. This seven hour Time to Detection (TTD) was faster than Cisco's estimated industry average of 100–200 days to detect a breach and FireEye's 146 days to detect a breach, and slightly faster than Cisco's best median TTD of nine hours to discover security issues.<ref name="Kenna17">{{cite web|title=How the Rise in Non-Targeted Attacks Has Widened the Remediation Gap|url=https://www.kennasecurity.com/wp-content/uploads/Kenna-NonTargetedAttacksReport.pdf|website=Kenna|publisher=Kenna Security|accessdate=11 August 2017}}</ref><ref name="InfocyteFireEye">{{cite web|last1=Gerritz|first1=Chris|title=Breach Detection by the Numbers: Days, Weeks or Years?|url=https://www.infocyte.com/blog/2016/7/26/how-many-days-does-it-take-to-discover-a-breach-the-answer-may-shock-you|website=Infocyte|publisher=Infocyte|accessdate=11 August 2017}}</ref>
OneLogin staff shut down the affected instances as well as the compromised AWS keys within several minutes to stop the intrusion and confirmed there were no other active threats. This was significantly faster than the industry average of 100–120 days to remediate existing vulnerabilities.<ref name="Kenna17" />
The company has since improved its monitoring of AWS API endpoint signals, strengthened AWS key management, enhanced infrastructure and application encryption, expanded threat hunting activities and created additional in-app risk mitigation tools.

'''Pepero Day''' is held annually on [[November 11]], and is an observance in [[South Korea]] similar to [[Valentine's Day]]. It involves the gifting or exchange of [[Pepero]] snacks, a line of [[chocolate]]-dipped [[cookie]] sticks, with the intention of displaying affection for friends and loved ones. It is held on this day due to the resemblance of Pepero sticks, which are vertical that mirror the shortened date of 11/11.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/nation/2014/11/511_167943.html|title=Pepero Day: Eight things you should know|date=2014-11-11|work=koreatimes|access-date=2018-10-30|language=en}}</ref>
==History== The exact origins of this day are unknown.<ref name="About Day">{{cite web |last=Imatome-Yun |first=Naomi |title=November 11th is Pepero Day |url=http://koreanfood.about.com/od/holidaysandoccasions/a/November-11th-Is-Pepero-Day.htm |publisher=About.com |accessdate=November 11, 2013}}</ref> The origins are usually traced to a news story set in 1983. In the story, two female [[middle school]] students in the [[Yeongnam]] region exchanged Pepero wishing that they would both become tall and thin.<ref name="Dict Day">{{cite web |url=http://terms.naver.com/entry.nhn?docId=68928&cid=386&categoryId=386 |script-title=ko:빼빼로데이 |publisher=Parkmungak |accessdate=November 11, 2013 |language=Korean |trans-title=Pepero Day}}</ref> However, there is some doubt about this story.<ref name="DJC Day">{{cite news |last=Gale |first=Alastair |url=https://blogs.wsj.com/korearealtime/2013/11/11/on-pepero-day-a-japanese-rival-lurks/ |title=On Pepero Day, a Japanese Rival Lurks |work=The Wall Street Journal |publisher=Dow Jones & Company |subscription=yes |date=November 11, 2013 |accessdate=November 11, 2013}}</ref> Some argue that the origin was due to the shape of 1’s in the date (November 11 – 11/11) resembling Pepero sticks,<ref name="About Day" /> while some others attribute the similarity of shapes as factors that attributed to the popularity but not its origin.<ref name="Dict Day" /><ref name="DJC Day" />
The fad spread with the idea that, for maximum effectiveness for height and thinness, one must eat 11 packets of Pepero on November 11, 11:11am and 11:11pm at 11 seconds exactly. From 1997, [[Lotte (conglomerate)|Lotte]] started to use the aforementioned school story to successfully promote Pepero Day. The trend led to other companies creating similarly shaped snacks to participate on Pepero Day.<ref name="Dict Day" /> {{As of|2012}}, [[Lotte (conglomerate)|Lotte]] was making 50% of its annual sales on Pepero Day.<ref name="DJC Day" /> {{As of|2013}}, several [[department store]]s including [[Hyundai Department Store]], [[Shinsegae]], and [[Lotte Department Store]] were benefiting for people celebrating the day while stores such as [[E-mart]] and [[Homeplus]] were specially displaying and selling peperos on the day.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.sportsseoul.com/read/economy/1268607.htm |title= [SS현장] '빼빼로 데이' 일부 소비자 "과소비 조장"…롯데마트 "안 사면 그만" |publisher=Sportsseoul.com |date=November 11, 2013 |language=Korean |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131111232204/http://news.sportsseoul.com/read/economy/1268607.htm |archivedate=2013-11-11 |deadurl=yes |accessdate=November 11, 2013}}</ref>
==Controversy== Pepero Day has been criticized for being a business tool of certain [[company|companies]] and for having high [[calorie]]s which is contradictory to its original meaning. Alternatives include "Garaetteok Day", which promotes Farmer’s Day through exchanges of [[garaetteok]] (sticks of white [[tteok]]).<ref name="Dict Day" />
==See also== * [[Pepero]] * [[Pocky & Pretz Day]] – a similar celebration in Japan, also held on 11 November * [[Singles' Day]] – a somewhat similar celebration in China, also held on 11 November
